sen.j: 祭神武甕槌命経津主命天児屋根命比売神
sen.e: Enshrined deities:Takemikazuchino mikoto, Futsunushino kami (Futsunushino mikoto), Amenokoyane no mikoto, and Hime no kami
Enshrined deities: Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto, Futsunushi-no-kami (Futsunushi-no-mikoto), Amenokoyane-no-mikoto, and Hime-no-kami
Enshrined deities: Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto, Futsunushi-no-kami (Futsunushi-no-mikoto), Amenokoyane-no-mikoto, and Hime-no-kami

sen.j: 社格式内社（名神大）・二十二社・官幣大社・勅祭社・別表神社
sen.e: Classification: Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha), Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki, one of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines designated during the Heian period), Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine), Chokusai-sha (shrine attended by imperial envoy), and Beppyo jinja (Shrines on the Special List)

Classification: Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha), Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki; one of Nijuni-sha Shrines, the 22 most important Shinto shrines designated during the Heian period; Kanpei-taisha, large-scale state shrine; Chokusai-sha, shrine attended by imperial envoy; and Beppyo jinja, Shrines on the Special List

Classification: Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha), Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki; one of Nijuni-sha Shrines, the 22 most important Shinto shrines designated during the Heian period; Kanpei-taisha, large-scale state shrine; Chokusai-sha, shrine attended by imperial envoy; and Beppyo jinja, Shrines on the Special List

sen.j: 創建神護景雲2年（768年）
sen.e: Foundation: in 768
Founded: 768
Founded: 768

sen.j: 例祭3月13日（春日祭）
sen.e: Reisai (regular festival): March 13 (Kasuga-matsuri Festival)
Reisai (regular festival): March 13 (Kasuga-matsuri Festival)
Reisai (regular festival): March 13 (Kasuga-matsuri Festival)

sen.j: 春日大社（かすがたいしゃ）は、奈良県奈良市の奈良公園内にある神社である。
sen.e: Kasuga-Taisha Shrine is located in Nara Park, Nara City, Nara prefecture.
Kasuga-Taisha Shrine is located in Nara Park, Nara City, Nara prefecture.
Kasuga-Taisha Shrine is located in Nara Park, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 旧称春日神社。
sen.e: Its former name is Kasuga-jinja Shrine.
Its former name is Kasuga-jinja Shrine.
Its former name is Kasuga-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大社）、二十二社の一社で、旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: It is classified as Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Engishiki and one of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines designated during the Heian period), and its former shrine classification is Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).
It is classified as a Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Engishiki and one of the Nijuni-sha Shrines, and its former shrine classification was Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).
It is classified as a Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Engishiki and one of the Nijuni-sha Shrines, and its former shrine classification was Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).

sen.j: 全国にある春日神社の総本社である。
sen.e: It is the Grand Head shrine of Kasuga-Taisha Shrines located nationwide.
It is the Grand Head Shrine of all Kasuga-Taisha Shrines in Japan.
It is the Grand Head Shrine of all Kasuga-Taisha Shrines in Japan.

sen.j: 藤原氏の守護神である武甕槌命と経津主命、祖神である天児屋根命と比売神を祀る。
sen.e: It enshrines Takemikazuchino mikoto and Futsunushino kami (Futsunushino mikoto)-- a guardian gods for the Fujiwara clan--and Amenokoyane no mikoto and Hime no kami--Soshin (ancestor honored as god).

It enshrines Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto and Futsunushi-no-kami (Futsunushi-no-mikoto), guardian gods of the Fujiwara Clan, and Amenokoyane-no-mikoto and Hime-no-kami, Soshin (ancestors honored as god) of the Fujiwara Clan.

It enshrines Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto and Futsunushi-no-kami (Futsunushi-no-mikoto), guardian gods of the Fujiwara clan, and Amenokoyane-no-mikoto and Hime-no-kami, Soshin (ancestors honored as god) of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: 四神をもって藤原氏の氏神とされ、春日神と総称される。
sen.e: These four deities collectively believed to be Ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) for the Fujiwara clan are called Kasuga no kami.
These four deities, collectively believed to be 'ujigami' (tutelary gods) of the Fujiwara Clan, are called Kasuga-no-kami.
These four deities, collectively believed to be ujigami (tutelary gods) of the Fujiwara clan, are called Kasuga-no-kami.

sen.j: 神紋は下がり藤。
sen.e: Its crest for a shrine is Sagari fuji (hanging wisteria).
The shrine's crest is a hanging wisteria (sagari fuji).
The shrine's crest is a hanging wisteria (sagari fuji).

sen.j: 武甕槌命が白鹿に乗ってやってきたとされることから、シカが神使とされる。
sen.e: The deer is considered as shinshi (a messenger of kami (god), because Takemikazuchino mikoto is believed to have come here riding on a white deer.
The deer is considered a 'shinshi' (a messenger of kami, or gods), because Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto is believed to have come here riding on a white deer.
The deer is considered a 'shinshi' (a messenger of kami, or gods), because Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto is believed to have come here riding on a white deer.

sen.j: 奈良・平城京に遷都された710年（和銅3年）、藤原不比等が藤原氏の氏神である鹿島神（武甕槌命）を春日の御蓋山に遷して祀った。
sen.e: In 710 when the national capital was transferred to Heijo-kyo in Nara, FUJIWARA no Fuhito transferred Kashima-no-kami (Takemikazuchino mikoto)--Fujiwara Clan's guardian god---to Mt. Mikasa in Kasuga to be enshrined there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 710 when the national capital was transferred to Heijo-kyo in Nara, FUJIWARA no Fuhito transferred Kashima-no-kami (Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto), the Fujiwara Clan's guardian god, to Mt. Mikasa in Kasuga to be enshrined there.

In 710 when the national capital was transferred to Heijo-kyo in Nara, FUJIWARA no Fuhito transferred Kashima-no-kami (Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto), the Fujiwara clan's guardian god, to Mt. Mikasa in Kasuga to be enshrined there.

sen.j: 春日神と称したのに始まる。
sen.e: The shrine started when the god was called Kasuga no kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The beginnings of the shrine date from when this god came to be called Kasuga-no-kami.
The beginnings of the shrine date from when this god came to be called Kasuga-no-kami.

sen.j: 社伝では、768年（神護景雲2年）に藤原永手が鹿島神宮の武甕槌命、香取神宮の経津主命と、枚岡神社に祀られていた天児屋根命・比売神を併せ、御蓋山の麓の四殿の社殿を造営したのをもって創祀としている。
sen.e: The shrine's biography says that it was founded when FUJIWARA no Nagate joined Takemikazuchino mikoto of Kashima-jingu Shrine, Futsunushino mikoto of Katori-jingu Shrine, and Amenokoyane no mikoto and Hime no kami enshrined in Hiraoka-jinja Shrine and erected four shrine buildings in the foot of Mt. Mikasa

The shrine's history says that it was founded when FUJIWARA no Nagate united Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto of Kashima-jingu Shrine, Futsunushi-no-mikoto of Katori-jingu Shrine, and Amenokoyan-no-mikoto and Hime-no-kami enshrined in Hiraoka-jinja Shrine and erected four shrine buildings at the foot of Mt. Mikasa

The shrine's history says that it was founded in 768 when FUJIWARA no Nagate united Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto of Kashima-jingu Shrine, Futsunushi-no-mikoto of Katori-jingu Shrine, and Amenokoyan-no-mikoto and Hime-no-kami enshrined in Hiraoka-jinja Shrine and erected four shrine buildings at the foot of Mt. Mikasa

sen.j: ただし、近年の境内の発掘調査により、神護景雲以前よりこの地で祭祀が行われていた可能性も出てきている。
sen.e: However, the recent excavation and research works suggested that Saishi (religious services) may have been held in this region before the Jingo Keiun era.
However, recent excavations have suggested that rituals may have been held in this region before the Jingo-keiun period (767-770).
However, recent excavations have suggested that rituals may have been held in this region before the Jingo-keiun period (767-770).

sen.j: 藤原氏の隆盛とともに当社も隆盛した。
sen.e: This shrine became prosperous with prosperity of the Fujiwara clan.
As the Fujiwara Clan became prosperous, so did the shrine.
As the Fujiwara clan became prosperous, so did the shrine.

sen.j: 平安時代初期には官祭が行われるようになった。
sen.e: Public rites and festivals started in the early Heian period.
Public festivals were held in the early Heian period.
Public festivals were held in the early Heian period.

sen.j: 当社の例祭である春日祭は、賀茂神社の葵祭、石清水八幡宮の石清水祭とともに三勅祭の一つとされる。
sen.e: Kasuga-matsuri Festival, a reisai (regular festival) of this shrine was one of sanchokusai (three great festivals designated by Japan's imperial court) along with Aoi-Matsuri Festival of Kamo-jinja Shrine and Iwashimizu-Sai Festival of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine.

Kasuga-matsuri Festival, a reisai (regular festival) of Kasuga-taisha Shrine, was one of the sanchokusai (three great festivals designated by the Imperial Court) along with Kamo-jinja Shrine's Aoi-Matsuri Festival and Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine's Iwashimizu-Sai Festival.

Kasuga-matsuri Festival, a reisai (regular festival) of Kasuga-taisha Shrine, was one of the sanchokusai (three great festivals designated by the Imperial Court) along with Kamo-jinja Shrine's Aoi-Matsuri Festival and Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine's Iwashimizu-Sai Festival.

sen.j: 850年（嘉承3年）には武甕槌命・経津主命が、940年（天慶3年）には、朝廷から天児屋根命が最高位である正一位の神階を授かった。
sen.e: The imperial rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) was conferred on Takemikazuchino mikoto and Futsunushino mikoto in 850 and Amenokoyane no mikoto in 940.
The imperial rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) was conferred on Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto and Futsunushi-no-mikoto in 850 and Amenokoyane-no-mikoto in 940.
The imperial rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) was conferred on Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto and Futsunushi-no-mikoto in 850 and Amenokoyane-no-mikoto in 940.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には「大和国添上郡 春日祭神四座」と記載されている。
sen.e: Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) describes:"our deities of Kasuga-matsuri Festival in the village of Yamamura in Sou upper district, Yamato province."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Jinmyocho (list of deities) in the Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) contains the passage, "our deities of Kasuga-matsuri Festival in the village of Yamamura in Soekami District, Yamato Province."

The Jinmyocho (list of deities) in the Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) contains the passage, 'our deities of Kasuga-matsuri Festival in the village of Yamamura in Soekami County, Yamato Province.'
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。地名を修正しました。

sen.j: また、名神大社に列し、月次・新嘗の幣帛に預るとも記されている。
sen.e: It also describes that the shrine is listed as a Myojin-taisha Shrine and heihaku (a sacramental strip of silk (offered to the gods)) was offered on monthly Niiname.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It also states that the shrine is listed as a Myojin-taisha Shrine and that heihaku (offerings of cloth to the gods) were offered at the Tsukinami and Niiname festivals.
It also states that the shrine is listed as a Myojin-taisha Shrine and that heihaku (offerings of cloth to the gods) were offered at the Tsukinami and Niiname festivals.

sen.j: 藤原氏の氏神・氏寺の関係から興福寺との関係が深い。
sen.e: The shrine has a close relation with Kofuku-ji Temple because they are connected with the Fujiwara clan--ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) and Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) of the clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The shrine, which houses the Fujiwara Clan's ujigami, has a close relationship with Kofuku-ji Temple, which is the clan's 'ujidera' (tutelary temple).
The shrine, which houses the Fujiwara clan's ujigami, has a close relationship with Kofuku-ji Temple, which is the clan's 'ujidera' (tutelary temple).

sen.j: 813年（弘仁4年）、藤原冬嗣が興福寺南円堂を建立した際、その本尊の不空絹索観音が、当社の祭神・武甕槌命の本地仏とされた。
sen.e: When FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu had Nanen-do Hall set up in Kofuku-ji Temple in 813, Takemikazuchino mikoto of this shrine was regarded as the honji-butsu (original Buddhist divinity) of Fukukensaku Kannon (Deity of Mercy)--the honzon (principal image of Buddha).of the temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu had the Nanen-do Hall built at Kofuku-ji Temple in 813, Kasuga-taisha Shrine's Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto was held to be the Shinto version of Fukukensaku Kannon (Amoghapasa), the honzon (principal image of Buddha).of the temple.

When FUJIWARA no Fuyutsugu had the Nanen-do Hall built at Kofuku-ji Temple in 813, Kasuga-taisha Shrine's Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto was held to be the Shinto version of Fukukensaku Kannon (Amoghapasa), the honzon (principal image of Buddha) of the temple.
sen.cmt: 文中のピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 神仏習合が進むにつれ、春日大社と興福寺は一体のものとなっていった。
sen.e: With the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism, Kasuga-Taisha Shrine and Kofuku-ji Temple became regarded as a united body.
With the syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism, Kasuga-Taisha Shrine and Kofuku-ji Temple became regarded as a united body.
With the syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism, Kasuga-Taisha Shrine and Kofuku-ji Temple became regarded as a united body.

sen.j: 11世紀末から興福寺衆徒らによる強訴がたびたび行われるようになった。
sen.e: There were frequent direct petitions of soldiers of Kofuku-ji Temple after the end of 11th century. direct petitions shinboku-doza (moving of the sacred tree)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Towards the end of the 11th century, warrior-monks from Kofuku-ji Temple often took part in direct 'goso' (literally, forceful protest).
Towards the end of the 11th century, warrior-monks from Kofuku-ji Temple often took part in direct 'goso' (literally, forceful protest).

sen.j: その手段として、春日大社の神霊を移した榊の木（神木）を奉じて上洛する「神木動座」があった。
sen.e: "Shinboku-doza (moving of the sacred tree)" was a means of such a direct petition, in which the soldiers went up to Kyoto under the authority of the Sakaki tree (shinboku (sacred tree)) into which a divine spirit of Kasuga Taisha Shrine was infused.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: One such means of 'goso' was the 'shinboku-doza' (moving of the sacred tree), in which the monks went up to Kyoto under the authority of the Sakaki tree (shinboku (sacred tree)) into which a divine spirit of Kasuga-taisha Shrine was infused.

One such means of 'goso' was the 'shinboku-doza' (moving of the sacred tree), in which the monks went up to Kyoto under the authority of the Sakaki tree (shinboku (sacred tree)) into which a divine spirit of Kasuga-taisha Shrine was infused.

sen.j: 明治4年に春日神社に改称し、官幣大社に列した。
sen.e: In 1871, it was renamed Kasuga-jinja Shrine and listed as a Kanpeitaisha.
In 1871, it was renamed Kasuga-jinja Shrine and listed as a Kanpeitaisha.
In 1871, it was renamed Kasuga-jinja Shrine and listed as a Kanpeitaisha.

sen.j: 1946年（昭和21年）12月に現在の春日大社に改称した。
sen.e: In December, 1946, it was presently renamed as Kasuga Taisha Shrine.
In December, 1946, it was given the present name of Kasuga-taisha Shrine.
In December 1946, it was given the present name of Kasuga-taisha Shrine.

sen.j: 春日造の本殿が四殿並んで建っている。
sen.e: There stand four main buildings of kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There are four honden built in a style known as kasuga-zukuri.
There are four honden built in a style known as kasuga-zukuri.

sen.j: 第一殿に武甕槌命、第二殿に経津主命、第三殿に天児屋根命、第四殿に比売神が祀られている。
sen.e: Takemikazuchino mikoto, Futsunushino mikoto, Amenokoyane no mikoto, and Himeno-kami were enshrined in the first shrine, the second shrine, third shrine, and the fourth shrine, respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto is enshrined in the first honden, Futsunushi-no-mikoto in the second, Amenokoyane-no-mikoto in the third, and Hime-no-kami in the fourth.
Takemikazuchi-no-mikoto is enshrined in the first honden, Futsunushi-no-mikoto in the second, Amenokoyane-no-mikoto in the third, and Hime-no-kami in the fourth.

sen.j: 拝殿はない。
sen.e: There is no Haiden (hall of worship).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There is no haiden (hall of worship).
There is no haiden (hall of worship).

sen.j: 一般の参拝者は幣殿の前にて、初穂料を納めて特別拝観を申し込んだ場合は本殿前の中門から参拝することになる。
sen.e: General visitors, who have paid hatsuho-ryo (ceremony fee) in front of the votive offering hall to request special viewing, pray at the Chumon gate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: General visitors, who have paid hatsuho-ryo (ceremony fee) in front of the votive offering hall to request special viewing, pray at the Chumon gate.
General visitors, who have paid hatsuho-ryo (ceremony fee) in front of the votive offering hall to request special viewing, pray at the Chumon gate.

tit.e: Setsumatsu sha (smaller shrine managed under the shrine)

sen.j: 広大な境内には多数の摂末社がある。
sen.e: There are many Setsumatsu sha in its large precinct.
There are many setsumatsusha in the shrine's large precinct.
There are many setsumatsusha in the shrine's large precinct.

sen.j: 本殿の東側には比売神の御子神として天押雲根命を祀る摂社若宮神社がある。
sen.e: East of the main building, Wakamiya shrine of sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity closely-related to that of a main shrine)) stands that enshrines Ameno-oshikumone-no-mikoto as mikogami (the child god in a shrine where parent-child gods are enshrined) of Hime no kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Wakimiya-jinja Shrine, a sessha (auxiliary shrine) that stands to the east of the honden, enshrines Amenooshikumone-no-mikoto, the mikogami (child god) of Hime-no-kami.
Wakimiya-jinja Shrine, a sessha (auxiliary shrine) that stands to the east of the honden, enshrines Amenooshikumone-no-mikoto, the mikogami (child god) of Hime-no-kami.

sen.j: 若宮神社、夫婦大国社を始めとする本殿東側の十二社は、「福の神十二社めぐり」として古来より崇敬を集めている。
sen.e: The twelve shrines including Wakamiya-jinja Shrine and Meoto-daikokusha Shrine that stand east of the main building were revered since ancient times as 'Pilgrimage to twelve shrines of The God of Good Fortune.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The twelve shrines, including Wakamiya-jinja Shrine and Meoto-daikokusha Shrine, that stand to the east of the honden have been revered since ancient times as the 'Pilgrimage to the twelve shrines of The God of Good Fortune.'

The twelve shrines, including Wakamiya-jinja Shrine and Meoto-daikokusha Shrine, that stand to the east of the honden have been revered since ancient times as the 'Pilgrimage to the twelve shrines of The God of Good Fortune.'

sen.j: 本殿廻廊の西南隅には、摂社・榎本神社（式内小社）がある。
sen.e: Enomoto-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-shosha) of sessha stands at the southeast corner of the main building's cloister..
The sessha Enomoto-jinja Shrine (listed as a minor shrine in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) stands at the southeastern corner of the honden's cloister.
The sessha Enomoto-jinja Shrine (listed as a minor shrine in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) stands at the southwestern corner of the honden's cloister.

sen.j: 榎本神社の祭神は当地の地主神であり、元々この地で祀られていた神であるとされる。
sen.e: The enshrined deity of Enomoto-jinja Shrine is jinushigami (god of an area of land), a god believed to have been originally enshrined in this area.
The enshrined deity of Enomoto-jinja Shrine is a jinushigami (god of an area of land), a god believed to have been originally enshrined in this area.
The enshrined deity of Enomoto-jinja Shrine is a jinushigami (god of an area of land), a god believed to have been originally enshrined in this area.

sen.j: 現在の祭神はサルタヒコであるが、中世までは巨勢姫明神とされていた。
sen.e: Sarutahiko is the deity presently enshrined but Kosenohime Myojin God had been enshrined until the Medieval Period.
Sarutahiko is the deity presently enshrined but Kosenohime Myojin was enshrined there until the medieval period.
Sarutahiko is the deity presently enshrined but Kosenohime Myojin was enshrined there until the medieval period.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 旬祭（毎月1日・11日・21日）
sen.e: Season festivals (every 1st, 11th, and 21st day of the month)
sen.cmt: 旬祭は、毎月3回、1日、11日、21日に行われているようですので、そのように訂正しておきました。http://www.kasugataisha.or.jp/manabu/manabu3.html
sen.e: Shunsai festivals - 1st, 11th, and 21st of every month
sen.cmt: "旬" here means 'a ten-day period', not season
sen.e: Shunsai festivals - 1st, 11th, and 21st of every month

sen.j: 神楽始式（1月3日）
sen.e: Kagura Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of kagura-dance) (January 3)
Kagura Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of kagura-dance) - January 3
Kagura Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of kagura-dance) - January 3

sen.j: 御祈祷始式（1月7日）
sen.e: Gokito Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of prayer) (January 7)
Gokito Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of prayer) - January 7
Gokito Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of prayer) - January 7

sen.j: 舞楽始式（1月10日）
sen.e: Bugaku Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of traditional Japanese Court dances) (January 10)
Bugaku Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of traditional Japanese Court dances) - January 10
Bugaku Hajime Shiki (the ceremony of traditional Japanese Court dances) - January 10

sen.j: 節分万燈籠（節分の日）
sen.e: Setsubun Bantoro Festival (the last day of winter according to the old calendar)
